Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E/Collaborative Research: Uncertainty Quantification of an Electromechanical Nonlinear Continuum Theory

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative research project is to develop an advanced materials modeling framework that integrates quantum mechanics into a macroscale continuum mechanics modeling framework for smart materials. The integration of fundamental physics of materials at nanometer scales within a macroscopic material model can have a tremendous impact on understanding the design of materials as well as create the possibility of quantifying parameter sensitivities and uncertainties in the models. To address this latter issue, novel uncertainty quantification methods will be formulated and implemented using advanced computations in a Bayesian statistical framework. The uncertainty quantification will provide probability densities of the macroscale parameters supported by quantum simulations. The deliverables will include homogenized stress, electric field, and energy relations that utilize both the local quantum material relations and probability densities that occur when approximating the model at larger length scales.

It is anticipated that the fusion of quantum-continuum scale material simulations will have a broad impact on understanding smart materials. These materials are being investigated for and applied in various biomedical, aerospace, automotive, and energy fields due to their unique functionality in solid state structures and devices. The new data analysis and computational techniques are expected to support this challenge to better understand advanced materials. This becomes particularly important in advancing the development of nanomaterials into larger scale structures that cannot be easily simulated directly with quantum models or approximate continuum theories. The results developed through this program will be integrated into engineering mechanics and mathematics courses. The computational methods will also be integrated into outreach programs at each university. Lastly, the results of this program will be introduced into an outreach program at a local museum where K-12 children and their parents learn about various aspects of engineering through monthly hands-on demonstrations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcome of our research led to mathematical methods to quantify the uncertainty and sensitivity of physical models used in engineering.  In particular, we used what is known as Bayesian statistics to guide approximations of complex quantum physics using more efficient computational models.  This was complemented by global sensitivity analysis which identifies the most important properties of a model and therefore provides insight into the most important qualities governing a material or engineered structure.  The uncertainty of these approximations were quantified with Bayesian statistics to ensure sufficient fidelity of our models such that they can be used to understand and design engineering systems.  To validate the approach, we studied a material that couples forces and shape changes with electrical inputs, known as ferroelectric materials.  These materials are known for their broad impact in aerospace, automotive, energy harvesting, civil infrastructure, and biomedical devices.  We provided new insights into appropriate ways to correlate quantum mechanical phenomenon with reduced order continuum (average) properties that can be used to study larger scale engineering structures.  Through our research, we educated students conducting the research, integrated the research results into existing and new university courses, and created and presented hands-on tutorials at many conferences such that others can apply these mathematical tools more broadly.  Attendees of these tutorials included academia, government, and industry.  The tutorial has grown in size and we therefore plan to continue the outreach efforts at future conferences.  


Last Modified: 04/01/2018
Modified by: William S Oates

  • This figure illustrates how we approximate quantum mechanical (DFT) energy in materials using reduced order (continuum) energy relations to accelerate computations of engineered materials and systems. The horizontal axis represents polarization and the vertical axis is energy density.

    William S Oates
    Uncertainty of Quantum Material Behavior
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The key outcome of our research led to mathematical methods to quantify the uncertainty and sensitivity of physical models used in engineering. In particular, we used what is known as Bayesian statistics to guide approximations of complex quantum physics using more efficient computational models. This was complemented by global sensitivity analysis which identifies the most important properties of a model and therefore provides insight into the most important qualities governing a material or engineered structure. The uncertainty of these approximations were quantified with Bayesian statistics to ensure sufficient fidelity of our models such that they can be used to understand and design engineering systems. To validate the approach, we studied a material that couples forces and shape changes with electrical inputs, known as ferroelectric materials. These materials are known for their broad impact in aerospace, automotive, energy harvesting, civil infrastructure, and biomedical devices. We provided new insights into appropriate ways to correlate quantum mechanical phenomenon with reduced order continuum (average) properties that can be used to study larger scale engineering structures. Through our research, we educated students conducting the research, integrated the research results into existing and new university courses, and created and presented hands-on tutorials at many conferences such that others can apply these mathematical tools more broadly. Attendees of these tutorials included academia, government, and industry. The tutorial has grown in size and we therefore plan to continue the outreach efforts at future conferences.
